However, because of the inherent difficulties of empirically capturing the complexities of a two-sided matching process, previous research has often focused on either the supply or demand characteristics of the process while neglecting the other.

Labor economics provides a strong theoretical basis for developing a matching perspective of director selection (Gale, 2001; Roth & Sotomayor, 1990). And, as previously mentioned, research recognizes the possibility of analyzing the director selection process from a labor market perspective (i.e., the market for corporate directors; G. F. Davis, 1993). Firms in the market for directors represent the demand side in the market, and director candidates represent the labor supply available to fill this demand. The market for corporate directors represents a unique labor market context given that a single director may serve concurrently on multiple boards and may accept more than one appointment at a time. Conversely, in typical labor markets, the selection process represents a many-to-one matching problem in that a single employer may hire several employees, but the employees do not join multiple firms simultaneously.

A matching perspective of director selection will require the employment of more sophisticated theorizing and methodological approaches to represent the selection process. From a theoretical perspective, research will need to delve into the dual motivations of potential directors and firms evaluating candidates. Integrating the research review here may be an initial step in understanding how the alignment of directors and firms emerges. Empirically, recent research in the management literature may provide some guidance to confronting the empirical challenges. For example, Mitsuhashi and Greve’s (2009) research on alliance formation may offer insights into approaching the matching problem of director selection. In this case, data limitations make assessing all potential matches difficult; however, using a random sample of potential matches or a limited sample of potential board seats may overcome some of these challenges. Following their approach, director selection research may attempt to limit the sample of potential director-board matches by focusing on a small population of directors and firms. For example, on the supply side, a sample of potential directors may include all CEOs in the Fortune 100, and, on the demand side, a sample of potential firms may include all Fortune 500 firms. Then, each potential match would represent an observation with director- and firm- or board-level data for each potential match. This approach would allow researchers to empirically compare actual matches with potential matches. Although this approach is not without its limitations, it does provide a closer approximation of the actual director selection process, and we believe this represents a critical area for future research.

sec.title: How Do Other Governance Mechanisms Influence the Director Selection Process?
sec.p: Boards of directors represent only one of several governance mechanisms (Jensen & Meckling, 1976; Shleifer & Vishny, 1997). Although governance research recognizes a number of different governance mechanisms, including ownership concentration, executive leadership structure, and the market for corporate control, director selection research often considers the director selection process as independent of these other governance mechanisms. However, research suggests that governance mechanisms may interact in ways that may complement (Kosnik, 1987; Tosi, Katz, & Gomez-Mejia, 1997) or substitute (Beatty & Zajac, 1994; Rediker & Seth, 1995) for one another. In either case, the other governance mechanisms currently in place may directly influence the director selection process and, in turn, the ultimate selection. This interaction of governance mechanisms suggests that research on director selection should consider how other governance mechanisms influence the director selection process.

For example, owners with larger shareholdings have greater incentives to ensure that management acts in their (the large owners’) best interests, and these owners may have significant power to enforce their preferences about management actions (Shleifer & Vishny, 1997). Similarly, these owners may have greater influence in who is nominated and appointed to a board. In support of this perspective, in 2010, the SEC adopted changes to the federal proxy rules to facilitate shareholder rights to nominate and elect directors. This ruling change requires that companies include individuals nominated by beneficial shareholders alongside those individuals nominated by management. In this regard, other governance mechanisms may have a direct influence on the selection process. These new changes raise a number of important questions. For example, do owners have different preferences for the type of individual selected to serve?

As examples related to other governance mechanisms, what role does CEO equity compensation have on his or her preferences regarding new directors? Does CEO duality have an effect on the selection process or outcome? How do changes in governance mechanisms affect the board? In short, there is rich potential when one considers interactions among governance mechanisms and the effect on director selection.

Another possible extension may be to simultaneously consider current top management team and board members when examining director selection. In this approach, from a rational perspective, the director selection choice may be based on how the potential director’s skills, knowledge, and other resources complement those of executives of the top management team and not just the existing board members. Questions might include the following: Do the backgrounds of the top management team members influence new director selection? Does top management team homogeneity or heterogeneity reflect similarly on the composition of the board of directors? How might top management team behavioral integration (Hambrick, 1994) influence the types of individuals selected for a board? Are there other social processes at work within the firm that affect new director selection?

sec.title: Examining the Gray Director
sec.p: Much of the previous research on director selection and board composition in general has used the simple director categorization of insiders versus outsiders (Dalton, Hitt, Certo, & Dalton, 2007). However, research suggests that this dichotomous representation of directors may be an oversimplification as some directors do not easily fall into the insider or independent–outsider categories (Baysinger & Zardkoohi, 1986; Finkelstein et al., 2009; Hillman et al., 2000). In particular, the gray director—a director who is not an employee of the focal firm but has substantial business dealings with it—represents an understudied phenomenon in the selection process.

Gray directors are clearly not independent (according to the recent Sarbanes-Oxley legislation), but their implications for governance practices are ambiguous. For example, from their perspective of director identities, Hillman and colleagues (2008) argue that directors may identify with other organizational stakeholders, such as customers and suppliers, and this identification may lead them to monitor and provide resources to benefit those other stakeholders. In this scenario, a gray director who has a strong identification with an external stakeholder may be more likely to monitor for the benefit of that stakeholder. At the same time, such a director’s willingness to provide resources to a firm may exhibit a curvilinear relationship such that at some level of identification, the director may actually draw resources from the focal firm to benefit the stakeholder group. Because of their relationship with the focal firm and its external stakeholders, the selection of gray directors may represent unique challenges during the selection process. Future research may begin to unravel the underlying firm-level motivations for selecting gray directors. The selection of a gray director also represents the intersection of the rational and socially embedded perspectives. On one hand, these directors may be brought on to provide critical resources (i.e., linkages to resource providers and stakeholders). However, at the same time, these director appointments are reflective of a firm’s socially embedded contexts and attempts to manage this interdependency (Pfeffer & Salancik, 1978).

sec.title: Director Selection during Organizational Decline
sec.p: As our review indicates, a fair amount of research considers different organizational contexts and how these contexts influence director selection decisions; however, there is still great opportunity to further contextualize the director selection process. Board scholars often suggest that firm context determines the importance of boards (e.g., Chatterjee & Harrison, 2001; Zahra & Pearce, 1989). In certain contexts, the decision of who serves on these boards may be less critical if the board plays a less significant role in the organization. Thus, context is an important factor in predicting who will be selected to serve on a board and why.

One context, in particular, that may influence director selection is organizational decline. Research suggests that directors may play some of their most important roles in this context (Chatterjee & Harrison, 2001; Lorsch & MacIver, 1989; Withers, Corley, & Hillman, in press). “Organizational decline is a condition in which a substantial, absolute decrease in an organization’s resource base occurs over a specified period of time” (Cameron, Kim, & Whetten, 1987: 224). As Lorsch and MacIver (1989) suggest, organizational decline often derives from a gradually emerging crisis that reflects both internal and external factors facing an organization. The firm’s resource availability begins to decrease as external constituents begin to see indicators of poor performance, and human capital (in the form of executives and other employees) begins to leave the organization (Hambrick & D’Aveni, 1992; Whetten, 1980). In this situation, directors can provide both monitoring and advice and counsel to address underlying causes of decline and resources to help enact corrective actions. However, director exit is often a part of the downward spiral that some firms find themselves in (Finkelstein et al., 2009; Hambrick & D’Aveni, 1992).

Because of the importance of directors in declining firms and the possible exit of some directors, the ability to attract directors that can provide monitoring and critical resources is imperative for turnaround efforts. Nonetheless, declining firms also face the challenge of attracting directors to a situation that may be very unattractive because of the time commitment and reputational costs that accompany trying to enact a turnaround. Thus, research is needed to explore how firms in these decline (or other crises) situations engage in the director selection process. For example, how do potentially stigmatized firms attract directors to their boards? What incentives might be provided to compensate directors for their time and the potential risks they face? How are directors who join a distressed firm perceived or valued by the market for corporate directors?

sec.title: Director Selection in a Post–Sarbanes-Oxley World
sec.p: As we mentioned in describing the formal process, the regulatory and institutional environments in which it occurs also affect director selection. No regulatory change has had the potential for greater impact on the selection process than Sarbanes-Oxley and the accompanying listing requirement changes (Monks & Minow, 2004). Sarbanes-Oxley regulation changed the requirements for committee membership, requiring independent directors to serve on audit committees (Green, 2005). Although this regulation did not directly address board composition or director selection processes, its impact on the listing requirements of the major stock exchanges has, in turn, influenced the selection process. For example, the New York Stock Exchange now requires that all listed firms have a governance committee composed entirely of independent outsiders, defines clearly what an independent outsider is, and mandates clear responsibilities for the committee. Those responsibilities include CEO performance evaluation and all new director nominations. As Hoskisson and colleagues (2009) report, after these changes, board independence increased as firms conformed to these institutional pressures (also see Linck, Netter, & Yang, 2009). However, research is only beginning to take stock of the overall impact these institutional reforms have had on boards, board composition, and overall governance (e.g., Linck et al., 2009; Wintoki, 2007).

For example, research is documenting a shift in the types of directors who are appointed to boards. Studying an earlier time period (i.e., 1973–1994), Mizruchi and colleagues (2006) find a decreasing proportion of bankers on corporate boards. The authors suggest that this decline is in part the result of the increasing prominence of chief financial officers. As the authors posit,

disp-quote.p: The increased prominence of the CFO meant that the CEO now had a financial specialist to consult on a regular basis. Bankers on the board as advisors were no longer as essential, which may account for their decline. Moreover, the financial tools available to the firm were becoming increasingly complex, and reliance on traditional sources of funding from banks and insurance companies declined. (2006: 316)

sec.p: However, Linck and colleagues (2009) find an increase in the proportion of financial experts (as well other support specialists and retired executives) in response to the requirements of having a designated financial expert on each board. Similarly, some executives are less likely to accept offers to serve as outside directors as a result of the increased personal risk of directorship service. In turn, these changes have increased the demand for outside directors while at the same time reducing the willingness of potential directors to serve (Linck et al., 2009).

As Sarbanes-Oxley and the accompanying listing requirement changes continue to have far-reaching impacts on the board, a number of areas for future research appear promising. For example, are there any unintended consequences of these regulatory and listing requirements that have influenced director selection? How does the decline in the number of inside directors affect board processes and overall governance? How do firms select new outside directors to compensate for the knowledge that insider directors formerly brought to boards? How have director incentives changed to accommodate the increase in personal risk for outside directors? Have these institutional changes reduced CEO influence over this selection process? If so, are CEOs finding more indirect ways to influence the selection process?

Returning to the question of why individuals are willing to serve, these recent regulatory changes also influence the candidates who are willing to serve on corporate boards. What is the profile of a current executive willing to serve on another board? What are the individual’s personal motivations underlying the decision to join a board? With more support specialists and retired executives on the board, does this change the subsequent director selection decision?

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Our review has highlighted a number of promising avenues for future research on director selection. By reviewing the state of knowledge on director selection and providing some integration across the two most frequent approaches taken (rational economic and social embeddedness), we hope to prompt future research on director selection. Our discussion section has highlighted a number of research questions and issues that we believe will bear fruit. We believe that the future holds great promise for director selection research and for research about corporate governance generally.
